1.action: Plugin usb which contains live image burned.
1.expected_results: User can choose boot from live image on usb stick from boot menu or command line option

3.expected_results: Live image can boot up with usb stick

1.action:
Boot into system and edit /etc/inittab to make sure that system enter at the run level 3 by default, this is done by changing the line   


id:5:initdefault  

to  

id:3:initdefault

2.action: Reboot system, and press "Tab" to enter "grub"

3.action: Get into the "kernel" line with the edit option  "e" and add "psplash=false text" at the end line.

5.action: If system ask you for a login type "root"
5.expected_results: System should boot to run level 3, showing the command prompt.

1.action:
Boot into system and edit /etc/inittab to make sure that system enter at the run level 5 by default, this is done by changing the line   

id:3:initdefault  

to  

id:5:initdefault

2.action: Reboot system, and press "Tab" to enter "grub"

3.action: Get into the "kernel" line with the edit option  "e" and add "psplash=false text" at the end line.

4.action:
Press "F10" or "ctrl+x" to boot system 
Note: The test is only for sato image.

1.action: launch several applications(like contacts, file manager, notes, etc)
1.expected_results: user could switch among multi applications and desktop

2.action: launch terminal

3.action: switch among multi applications and desktop

4.action:
close applications 
Note: The case is for sato image only.

1.action: Boot the system and check internet connection is on .

2.action: Launch connmand-properties (up-right corner on desktop)

3.action:
Choose  Ethernet device and set a valid static ip address for it. 
For example, in our internal network, we can set as following: 
ip address: 10.239.48.xxx 
Mask: 255.255.255.0 
Gateway (Broadcast): 10.239.48.255

1.action: Launch connmand-properties (up-right corner on your desktop).

2.action: Check if Ethernet device can work properly with static IP, doing "ping XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX", once this is set.

3.action: Then choose DHCP method for Ethernet device in connmand-properties.

4.action: Check with 'ifconfig" and "ping" if Ethernet device get IP address via DHCP.
4.expected_results: Ethernet device can get dynamic IP address via DHCP in connmand .

1.action: Launch connman-properties after system booting

2.action: choose "offline mode" and check the connection of all network interfaces
2.expected_results: All connection should be off after clicking "offline mode" .

1.action: boot system and launch terminal; check output of "date" and launch script "continue.sh"

2.action: echo "mem" > /sys/power/state

3.action: After system go into S3 mode, move mouse or press any key to make it resume (on NUC press power button)

5.action:
Check if application can work as normal 
continue.sh as below: 
 
#!/bin/sh 
 
i=1 
while [ 0 ] 
do 
 echo $i 
 sleep 1 
 i=$((i+1)) 
done
5.expected_results: Screen should resume back and script can run continuously incrementing the i's value from where it was before going to standby state. Date should be the same with the corresponding time increment.

1.action: Start up system

2.action: run "top" command and check if there is any process eating CPU time

3.action: make system into standby and resume it

4.action: run "top" command and check if there is any difference with the data before standby
4.expected_results: There should be no big difference before/after standby with "top" .

1.action: boot system and launch terminal

check ping status

1.action: Download ABAT test suite from internal git repository, git clone git://tinderbox.sh.intel.com/git/abat

2.action: Apply following patch to make it work on yocto environment

3.action: Run "./abat.sh" to run ABAT test refer to abat.patch
3.expected_results:
All ABAT test should pass. 
Note : If below 3 fails appears ignore them. 
- start up X server fail.. due is already up 
- module [intel_agp] 
- module [i915]

1.action: Run "x11perf -aa10text" and "x11perf -rgb10text"

2.action: Get the FPS result and compare it with upstream graphics data on Sandybridge
2.expected_results: There should not be big regression between Yocto and upstream linux .

1.action: Run fdisk command to create partition on SATA disk.
1.expected_results: The SATA device can mount, umount, read and write.

2.action:
Mount/Umount 
  mke2fs /dev/sda1 
  mount -t ext2 /dev/sda1 /mnt/disk  
  umount /mnt/disk

3.action:
Read/Write (filesystem) 
  touch /mnt/disk/test.txt 
  echo abcd > /mnt/disk/test.txt 
  cat /mnt/disk/test.txt

4.action:
Read/Write (raw) 
  dd if=/dev/sda1 of=/tmp/test bs=1k count=1k  
  This command will read 1MB from /dev/sda1 to /tmp/test

1.action: Run media player and load a media file
1.expected_results: Media player correctly open audio/video file

2.action: Verify that seek and volume control are present
2.expected_results: Seek bar and volume control are present

3.action: Verify that selecting the speaker icon opens the volume control

4.action: Verify you can increase and decrease volume level with the volume control
4.expected_results: Volume level must be increased and decreased

5.action: Observe that slider on the seek bar moves along with the video/audio play
5.expected_results: Video/audio file can be played and slider moves along with the video/audio play

6.action: Verify you can navigate the video with the slider back and forward
6.expected_results: The slider can move back and forward in the seek bar

7.action: Verify that seek and volume control are functional in full screen mode
7.expected_results: Press the full screen mode icon, seek bar and volume control must work fine

8.action: Verify that pressing << or >> while playing a file makes the slide goes slow/backwards or faster

1.action: 1.Check if watchdog device exist in /dev/ directory. Run command echo 1 > /dev/watchdog and wait for 60s. Then, the target will reboot.
1.expected_results: The watchdog device exist in /dev/ directory and can reboot the target.

1.action: Read time from RTC registers.  root@localhost:/root> hwclock -r  Sun Mar 22 04:05:47 1970 -0.001948 seconds
1.expected_results: Can read and set the time from RTC.

2.action: Set system current time  root@localhost:/root> date 062309452008

3.action: Synchronize the system current time to RTC registers  root@localhost:/root> hwclock -w

4.action: Read time from RTC registers  root@localhost:/root> hwclock -r

5.action: Reboot target and read time from RTC again

1.action: Connect the board's first serial port to your workstation and then start up your favourite serial terminal so that you will be able to interact with the serial console. If you don't have a favourite, picocom is suggested:   $ picocom /dev/ttyS0 -b 115200
1.expected_results: The system can boot up without problem

2.action: Power up or reset the board and press a key on the terminal when prompted to get to the U-Boot command line

3.action: Set up the environment in U-Boot:  => setenv ipaddr   => setenv serverip

4.action: Download the kernel and boot:  => tftp tftp $loadaddr vmlinux => bootoctlinux $loadaddr coremask=0x3 root=/dev/nfs rw nfsroot=: ip=::::edgerouter:eth0:off mtdparts=phys_mapped_flash:512k(boot0),512k(boot1),64k@3072k(eeprom)
